Inside the House leadership scramble.

                AP Photo

            By 
Lauren French

09/29/15 11:39 AM EDT
The right-leaning Republican Study Committee will host candidates for House GOP leadership posts at a forum next week.
Candidates for speaker, majority leader and majority whip were invited to address the group’s weekly lunch meeting, according to an email sent to lawmakers on Tuesday. The group, chaired by Rep. Bill Flores of Texas, is also asking candidates to fill out a "RSC’s 2015 Republican Leadership Survey" that asks contenders to outline their opinions on a series of contentious issues facing the GOP caucus.  
The survey, which was obtained by POLITICO, asks candidates if they support a continuation of a ban on earmarks, their position on the Export-Import Bank and their vision for House procedures and process. 
Adhering to "regular order" has become a major point of contention for conservatives who rebelled against Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio).
“The full lunch will be dedicated to this important conversation about how House Republicans can advance the conservative principles embodied in the RSC agenda: growing America’s economy; fixing Washington’s fiscal nightmare; restoring our national security; protecting American values of life, family, marriage, and religious freedom; and restricting the federal government to its constitutionally limited role,” the RSC email says.
The Republican Study Committee is a longtime conservative group within the House that includes the majority of the caucus. It was designed to push the conference to the right on policy. Members of the RSC split from the group earlier this year to create the House Freedom Caucus, which has generally adopted a more aggressive posture with Republican leaders.
 HFC members are planning endorsement hearings for the next two weeks.
 The RSC lunch is Oct. 7.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Candidates for speaker, majority leader and majority whip were invited to address the group’s weekly lunch meeting.
title: Republican Study Committee invites leadership candidates in for debate
